comments.commentBody: All forms of electronic media depend on a few, quite vulnerable chokepoints, whether from a hacker, the government, an enemy, a sunspot, or a corporation. When one of those chokepoints is closed down, paper, ranging from leaflets tacked to light poles to full-fledged newspapers, will again be the method of news distribution, even if only temporarily. Whether mimeograph, carbon paper, or something that will be devised when the need presents itself, the printed word will remain accessible to almost everyone, media not dependent on the goodwill of corporations, the government, or others.

I'm a software entrepreneur in Colorado who has started multiple companies.  Easily the best people I've worked with have been ex-military.  Their sense of duty, and ability to work in a team is second to none.  The gentlemen I've worked with have also been the brightest engineers I've run across.  Leaders through and through.

As I am reading this Article I am thinking about those undergraduate students protesting and just standing around at night in some sort of public display of outrage that their coach at Penn State was fired. If that is the biggest issue they then those kids have lived a charmed life. These Marines can give those children some perspective.

Boy, I could not agree more with the sentiment of comments 1-4.  I truly hope the players decertify and form their own league, since the smug greed and paternalism of the owners and Stern is outrageous. I mean, the latest was his comment today blaming the "greedy agents" for the problems.   Oh, and that it will "take 3 months" to teach the players that decertification is a losing strategy.  The "best offer" from the owners, cuts the players salaries by 20%, and basically eliminates free agency. No other industry is so monopolistic as pro sports, and it is outrageous that in free-market-loving America the right wing is the one embracing, but only for "uppity" players, a controlled and dictated salary.  None of us reading this would accept being told where we can work or how much we could make...SHAME on you, David Stern and your avaricious oligarchic billionaire cohort of owners. You are letting your unfettered greed destroy a game of poetry and beauty.

As a lifetime journo (ink in veins, RSI in fingers), I will not shed a tear for the loss of paper. Consuming words, ideas and opinions will still go on. Earlier commenters are right about the heavy industrial modus operandi (except I've never seen a diesel press!). Paper production is clunky and supremely inefficient both in terms of raw materials and human resources. But then we'll probably be saying the same thing in a few decades about html and server parks. Life goes on...

There are two vets and three community college transfer students in my small (~20 students) language course at Columbia. They bring a lot to the class, in terms of life experience, motivation, and worldview. At times it's clear that they don't have the same academic preparation as the other students, but what they lack in background they make up in earnestness and diligence. I think it's great Columbia has made such an effort to recruit them.

"The Jets should win easily — the Patriots have only one starting-caliber cornerback to handle three very good Jets receivers — but “let us again bid fond farewell to the glorious Patriots” conversations that will dominate the following week make it almost not worth the trouble. "

What do you like on your crow!

The veterans I knew at university did often seem mature and savvy, but often too they were over 25-years-old. I was eligible for the draft only one year—when I was 25-years-old and I do not believe I would have blessed the services. My professors at university often earned degrees after the Second World War, while my cohorts were drafted after they had earned degrees. I do not know whether that made them better soldiers or troubling one. I don't really know.

I like the notion of young people earning tuition by serving in the military or in other such national service. That would not be compulsory but might build character and nurture maturity.
To quote the great sportswriter Dan Jenkins: "The Patriots dough-popped the dog-ass Jets." Ouch. Lesson from evil master Bill Belichick to student Rex: Talk less, win more.

Print reflects a stubborn and elitist nostalgia. I subscribe to this newspaper's digital edition. I really enjoy the quality of its articles, comments from its readers and the broad depth of its many news departments that are relying more and more on video feeds. That's the only reason I am here right now typing in this comment section. I get real value for the monthly fee of its paywall. But also subscribing to this newspaper's print edition makes about much sense as having a landline phone in my apartment.
But subscribing also to its print edition would be like having a landline phone in my apartment.

Walt, it was a team loss in every sense of the word. The special teams had their worst game of the season, the O-line (with Mangold healthy) had by-far its worst game, and the defense --- well, maybe it's a tie for the worst game with the Oakland game. It's too easy to blame it all on Sanchez (there will be all sorts of silly blog posts and expert analysis doing that). The Jets were just too sloppy in every phase, starting with poor goal-to-go play selection on the opening drive and then the missed chip shot FG attempt... and one problem cascaded onto another as the game went on.

So it will be another year of fighting for a Wild Card spot --- and --- if they can get it, having to win playoff games on the road. Even if they do qualify, this year the Jets' appear too inconsistent to mount any sort of deep playoff run.

That said: If you had told me a month ago when they were 3-3 after the ugly win over the Dolphins that the Jets would be 5-4, I'd have taken it. No team in the AFC has fewer than 3 losses... so, at the very least, we won't be witness to a team playing out the string.

Small comfort, I'm sure.

I am currently a master's degree student at Columbia and was heartened to learn of my university's commitment to veterans.  I, myself, am a rather unconventional student.  I am quite a bit older than my fellow classmates.  Nevertheless, I have been welcomed as part of the Columbia college community and love attending school.  I am glad that Columbia University has chosen to distinguish itself in this manner.  I can only hope other universities follow their lead.

Why don't they just make everyone pay the Social Security tax? It certainly is not just hat only those who get a employee check get taxed with 22 Entitlement programs for the poor. Yet everyone has the right to vote. Everyone may have a Social Security number, but not a Social Security tax. It started in 1935 and was for retirement and children crippled from polio.
In the 1960s, 22 Entitlement programs were added but for only the employees to pay. If you are the employer, the farmer, the state worker, the rancher, the railroad worker, are you paying for the poor that you have a right to vote others pay?
Why is our country poor. If you want to vote, you have moral obligation to pay your share of the taxes it brings upon us. Having so many cheating the U.S. Constitution is our biggest problem. It doesn't seem like that should be so hard to fix. Where is the Supreme Court that defends our U.S. Constitution? Poverty is our national face and a disgrace to our flag and our soldiers. If it isn't fixed, it can only impoverish more.
We can't create jobs, when we have created robots and electrical and mechanical instruments to do it for us.
So why not just go for fairness. Do we have a populous with the moral stamina to be fair and just? Or just fascist fools. Fascist target people and punish problems. it is hard place to be, trying to live among the blindness of private education. We can have a nice America again. But only with fairness. Nations do fall
of their own wrong doing wether in war or in peace times.

Kudos to Columbia for thinking outside of the box. One hopes that there is an opportunity for some of the more typical 18-21 year old undergrads to interact with these outstanding men and women. These service men and women may be earning a college degree, but it is the students and faculty with whom they interact who will be getting the "higher" education.
The life experiences and maturity of the individuals described in the article exceeds what most of us achieve in a lifetime. Those of us who are less heroic should consider the value of a gap year of true service to those less fortunate before students enter college.
I hope this article instills a mad rush of competition among colleges at all levels to recruit veterans, and that traditional high school grads look at this aspect of a diverse student body when deciding where to go to college. It's more than the courses, the sports teams, the parties. It is about the people.

Unfortunately the new changes to the Post-911 GI Bill will keep most vets out of places like Columbia. The changes that went into effect this past August limit the maximum tuition per year to $17,500. That is maybe 1 semester at a place like Columbia.

I go to Fordham and was nervous that I would be forced transfer since I am inheriting over $100k in loans from my fiance. Thankfully they grandfathered students in who were already in programs.

A little perspective on veterans in the classroom: This past Friday was obviously Veteran's Day. At Fordham, vets are allowed to the day off without being penalized. I have an 830 class Friday mornings. More than half of the kids were absent, but the 2 veterans in the class (myself included) were both in attendance, and I was headed straight there after working an overnight shift.

The GI Bill and other veteran education programs are amazing. This is a tremendous way to improve the education level in this country. I am truly thankful for the opportunity that I have been afforded.

"In their recipe for follow-up legislation, Democrats stipulate that the individual tax rate should be no higher than 35 percent, and that the new tax code should be 'as progressive as current law.'"
The pathetic democrat party is essentially even more dangerous than the republican party, since, unlike the contemporary rep party which is overtly a far-right party, the dems continue their foul 3-card monte game of deception, of seducing the Americans into thinking that the dem party is, despite all odds and appearances and objective data, somehow the American Left, because, uh, they are, you see, progressive; I mean, they are pro-gay marriage, after all, right?
You might be the single, broke parent of 3 minors, destitute, homeless, unemployed, uninsured and riddled with cancer, utterly hopeless, but, hey, the dems are for gay marriage - that should be enough to carry your sorry bottom through the frigid winter!
No such thing as a Left party in this country: both parties are well right of center and, as such, against the 99%, gay or not, black or white, immigrant or Native American.
Voting for the dems is perfectly wasteful and self-deceiving and merely delaying the inevitable day when the dems themselves will tell us point blank to get our lazy bottoms on the plantation and start picking at that cotton, or else.
Occupy the DNC.

As a military veteran at the age of 33, I was a wildly non-traditional student at Middlebury College in 1985. Then, as a graduate instructor in English Literature at the University of Iowa in 1989, I discovered that one of the two best students I ever had was an Army vet with whom I otherwise had little in common (or so I thought). There is no comparison: I would take a military vet as a student over any given 18-year-old "in a New York minute," as that vet once told me. That any of our so-called "elite" institutions might balk only speaks to their own intellectual deficiency.

My spouse has had veterans in his university courses (he's a professor). He is always interested in having military veterans in his courses for their mature demeanor and any insights they can bring from their military experience, but he doesn't treat them differently or patronize. Bottom line, you have to show up and do the work in his class, no matter who you are.
Because academic work is demanding, I hope less-resourced schools (such as state universities) are making sure to support the veterans they admit. Too often schools admit with good intentions, but fail to support afterwards. We have seen this with minority recruiting, open admissions and so forth -- bright students who are not prepared need support, at the right time and of the right kind.

Clearly, this means that the US should have its credit downgraded --again.

If revenues cannot be raised, then expenditures should. And there is much, much waste. Cutting the military, as promised in case there is no deal, is in fact the best first step.

Given we must borrow for our daily operations, borrowing less is actually an excellent defense move. A country can only be a as strong militarily as its economy, and every bit of borrowing from our frenemies makes us weaker.

For example, outside of a few hot spots (the Middle East, Korea) no military bases are needed --they just drain our treasure. And, certainly the US, basically broke and insolvent, can no longer afford to invest in a future nuclear arsenal.

Now, cutting Social Security and Medicare, programs that benefit Americans here in this country, is total madness. Doing so weakens the country, makes our people less productive, and places more strain on the dwindling Middle Class. Why on earth, are our politicians (Democrats especially) so timorous and so weak!!!

What these colleges and universities are doing is right, proper and moral.

The question I must ask is, how do these middle-twenty students entering undergrad compare with other students their age who have returned to undergraduate from other walks of life. How much of the difference is the military vs the maturity of age and knowing what you want and going after it.

Most 18-year old freshman have none of these.

This is ludicrous. We borrow 40 cents of every dollar we spend. We can't keep that up.

We need to eliminate all subsidies of oil, solar, wind, ethanol and the like. We need to eliminate all federal grants to any private entity, especially non profits. Non profits should lose all tax advantages at once.

We need to send student loans back to the private sector. We need to eliminate Pell grants. We need to repeal Obamacare, root and branch.

We need to bring all our troops home and muster out those not needed to effectively secure our borders. This means shooting intruders. We need to cancel all new weapons systems.

We need to assure that no bank or stock brokerage will every be bailed out again. Ditto auto makers.

We need to eliminate all federal influence over and investment in education at any level.

We need to eliminate whole departments, starting with Energy and Commerce, and the TSA, and a number of others as well. The remaining departments should take immediate 20% cuts in personnel and budget authority.

The beast is far too large and needs to be cut down to size.

The Europeans, like America, are making the error of focusing on debt during a deep economic downturn, instead of focusing on growth and job creation.  The lessons of history, especially the Great Depression, is that cutting state spending during a huge economic downturn will worsen deficits by slashing growth.  The time to balance budgets is when the economy is growing, not when it is shrinking.  This is the same error which was made during the early 1930's.

As a Captain with Alameda County Fire Department ( East San francisco Bay area ) I can attest to the fact that some of the greatest and most dedicated new firefighters I've had the chance to work with are the Marines and Army vets that we've hired and put through our academy. Our firefighter academy and two year probationary period are probably tough, but not anywhere as tough as a tour in the Middle East. Hire a Veteran!

How stupid are the owners? How stupid do they think the players are? Let the market set the salaries for athletes. Any owner who wants to keep payroll down is free to do so, unless of course that owner wants the best players. If you want the best, you must pay for it.

And while we're at it Congress needs to curtail the anti-trust exemptions enjoyed by professional sports leagues. Public financing of privately owned arenas and stadia should be banned by state constitutions. And there should be no tax deductible status for any educational institution that runs a quasi-professional sports team.

Many wonder how the Occupy sites are being financed and supported. I do not pretend to have the complete answer, but I have donated cash at two sites in Washington, DC and have seen others donating cash and supplies at these sites as well. I have also been told that area churches are taking in Occupy members during difficult weather, as well as donating supplies.

I have supported the protesters at the DC sites because they appear to be conducting themselves peacefully and because they are a visible sign of the unease that many Americans are feeling due to a difficult economy coupled with growing income inequality.

The Occupy movement is not perfect, but it is a possible catalyst for a more equitable approach to our country's economic problems. I am glad that the occupiers have taken action in Washington.
